quizzes.title: Literature Quiz: Novel and Film
quizzes.description: Test your literature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Literature, seinfeld, line. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This 1990s song, which is supposed to describe apocalyptic events, ends with the line one day all 7 will die.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 7

questions.question: In the crime thriller Se7en, that deals with a series of murders inspired by the seven deadly sins, Joe Doe, the murderer, admits that he, himself, is guilty of this sin.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: envy

questions.question: Fannie Flag wrote this 1991 Academy Award-nominated movie, starring Kathy Bates and Jessica Tandy, which was based on her best selling-novel written 4 years earlier.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fried Green Tomatoes

questions.question: This 1990 film featuring Harrison Ford and Brian Dennehy was an adaptation of the Scott Turows novel of the same name about of a prosecutor charged with the murder of his female colleague.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Presumed Innocent

questions.question: This 1994 film, nominated for four Academy Awards and directed and produced by Robert Redford was based on Richard Goodwins book Remembering America: A Voice From the Sixties.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Quiz Show

questions.question: Based on a Pulitzer prize winning novel by Michael Cunningham this 2002 movie featured Nicole Kidman and Julianne Moore.

options.text: Home at the End of the World

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Hours

questions.question: This film directed by Taylor Hackford was based on a novel by Andrew Neiderman and featured Keanu Reeves and Charlize Theron.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Devils Advocate

questions.question: In the Seinfeld episode The Seven, this character revealed that he wanted to name his first child Seven.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Costanza

questions.question: The movie The Seven Year Itch contains the iconic scene, in which Marilyn Monroe has her dress blown up by a passing train. What line does she deliver when this happens?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Isnt it delicious?

questions.question: What book in the popular Harry Potter series contains a chapter titled The Seven Potters?

options.text: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

questions.question: This 1999 film, based on the novel The Positronic Man, was co-written by Isaac Asimov and Robert Silverberg and starred Robin Williams. It was nominated for Academy award for best make-up.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bicentennial Man

questions.question: Jean-Jacques Annauds movie Seven Years in Tibet is based on the experiences of Austrian mountaineer Heinrich Harrer, who befriends the Tibetan spiritual leader, known as the Dalai Lama. The word lama is generally translated as guro or teacher. What does the word dalai mean in Mongolian?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: ocean

questions.question: This remake of a Dino Risi film from 1974 was based on the Italian novel Il buio e il miele (Darkness and Honey) by Giovanni Arpino, starred Al Pacino and was nominated for four Academy awards, winning one of them.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Scent of a Woman

questions.question: The biography of Nobel prize winning economist and mathematician John Nash, written by Sylvia Nasar, inspired this 2001 movie directed by Ron Howard, which was nominated for 8 Academy awards and won four of them.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Beautiful Mind

questions.question: What bands 7th studio album was titled Seventh Son of a Seventh Son?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Iron Maiden

quizzes.title: Literature Quiz: Novel and List
quizzes.description: Test your literature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Literature, condition, fiction. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What fantasy novel, focusing on the adventures of the Pevensie siblings and set approximately in 1940, appeared on Time magazines 100 Best English-language Novels?

options.text: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe

questions.question: This novel by Jack Kerouac, regarded as the defining work of the Beat Generation, is based on the spontaneous trips made by the author and his friends.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: On the Road

questions.question: This British authors novels Brideshead Revisited and A Handful of Dust both appeared on the list of Time magazines list of 100 Greatest Novels.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Evelyn Waugh

questions.question: A neurological condition, characterised by altered perceptions of body image and visual illusions, was named after this character from childrens literature.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alice in Wonderland

questions.question: What novel on Time magazines Best Novels list follows Holden Caulfield, a character that has come to be associated with teenage angst and rebellion?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Catcher in the Rye

questions.question: This authors Pulitzer Prize-winning novel American Pastoral and his 1969 bestseller Portnoys Complaint were both included in Time magazines 100 Best Novels list.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Philip Roth

questions.question: This 1997 science fiction movie directed by Robert Zemeckis was adapted from Carl Sagans novel of the same title.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Contact

questions.question: This economic term, derived from the name of a folklore hero, refers to income redistribution.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robin Hood effect

questions.question: This Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, set in the fictional tired old town of Maycomb, Alabama, is narrated by six-year-old Scout Finch.

options.text: The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: To Kill a Mockingbird

questions.question: Midnights Children, one of the books on Time magazines list of 100 Greatest Novels, was written by this author, who was sentenced to death following the publication of one of his literary works.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Salman Rushdie

questions.question: What allegorical novel, included on Time magazines 100 Greatest Novels list, follows a group of young boys marooned on a desert tropical island?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lord of the Flies

questions.question: This novel by Theodore Dreiser, included in Time magazines 100 Best Novels list, tells the story of a young man, Clyde Griffiths and deals with subjects such as religion, abortion and capital punishment.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: An American Tragedy

questions.question: Based on a 1983 book by Dick King-Smith, this 1995 Australian film directed by Chris Noonan was nominated for seven Academy Awards.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Babe

questions.question: What 18th century English writer depicted Man Friday, whose name has become an expression used to describe a loyal male personal assistant?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Daniel Defoe

questions.question: Which of the following acknowledged literary works was left out of the list of 100 Best English-language Novels, published in Time magazine in 2006?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: all of these

quizzes.title: Literature Quiz: Ernest Hemingway and Definition
quizzes.description: Test your literature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Literature, definition, zest. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: On what date was Ernest Hemingway wounded, while performing his duties as a WW I ambulance driver?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: July 8, 1918

questions.question: Which of these eponyms, derived from Jonathan Swifts novel Gullivers Travels, means a crude person, lacking in intelligence?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: yahoo

questions.question: This authors best-selling novel brought the term Pollyana into the English language to describe an illogically and blindly optimistic person.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Eleanor H. Porter

questions.question: Tartuffe, whose name has come to mean a hypocrite, especially one who affects religious piety, is the protagonist of a comedy by this playwright.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Molière

questions.question: In 1920 Ernest Hemingway accepted a job at this Canadian newspaper, where he met Morley Callaghan.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Toronto Star

questions.question: In Our Time was first published in 1925 and marked Hemingways American debut.  Which of the following short story titles is not part of this collection?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Killers

questions.question: At the age of seventeen Ernest Hemingway began working as a reporter for The Kansas City Star, where he remained for how long?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: six months

questions.question: What Ernest Hemingway novel was published in 1950, following For Whom the Bell Tolls?

options.text: Across the River and Into the Trees
The Old Mean and the Sea

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Across the River and Into the Trees

questions.question: Earnest Hemingway was born in 1899 in a Chicago suburb, and later attended this high school.

options.text: Oak Park and River Forest High School

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oak Park and River Forest High School

questions.question: The adjective Falstaffian, meaning jovial and with zest for life, is derived from the name of the fat knight Sir John Falstaff, who is featured in this Shakespearean comedy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Merry Wives of Windsor

questions.question: Which of these eponyms, derived from the name of a character created by Charles Dickens, is not correctly matched with its definition?

options.text: Gradgrind - a person interested only in cold facts
Fagin - an adult who instructs children in crime

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pickwickian - haughty, conceited

questions.question: In his 1940 novel For Whom the Bell Tolls, Ernest Hemingway tells the story of Robert Jordan, a U.S. guerrilla warrior serving in the Spanish Civil War. who is given the assignment to blow up a bridge near what Spanish city?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Segovia

questions.question: The Old Man and the Sea brought Ernest Hemingway enormous success and earned him the Noble Prize in Literature in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1954

questions.question: What is the definition of the term dogberrysm, which is derived from Shakespeares play Much Ado About Nothing?

options.text: a seemingly small but actually crucial weakness
striving for power at the price of spiritual values
the unintentional misuse of a word by confusion with one of similar sound, usually creating a comic effect

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the unintentional misuse of a word by confusion with one of similar sound, usually creating a comic effect

questions.question: What Nobel Prize-winning author depicted fictional character George F. Babbitt, whose surname has become synonymous with a business or professional man who conforms unthinkingly to dominant middle-class standards?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sinclair Lewis

quizzes.title: Literature Quiz: Novel and Title
quizzes.description: Test your literature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Literature, title, shute. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This novel by Nevil Shute is set in the future after WWIII. Due to the nuclear fallout, only land in the southern hemisphere is inhabitable.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: On the Beach

questions.question: Name the author of the 19th century novels A Captain at Fifteen, Around the World in 80 Days and Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jules Verne

questions.question: In 1946 this author received the Nobel Prize in Literature. He was born in Württemberg, Germany to a Christian missionary family that worked in India. He is best known for his novel Steppenwolf.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hermann Hesse

questions.question: This post-World War II satirist wrote a popular anti-war novel, whose title has become a commonly used idiomatic phrase, referring to a a no-win situation or a double bind.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joseph Heller

questions.question: What post-modern novel, following the experiences of Billy Pilgrim, contains the prayer, God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, the courage to change the things that I can, and the wisdom to know the difference”?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Slaughterhouse-Five

questions.question: This Ernest Hemingway book, published posthumously, tells the story of a bullfighter named Antonio Ordonez.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Dangerous Summer

questions.question: The title of Ken Keseys novel One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest is derived from which of the following?

options.text: a short story by a friend of Keseys

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: a nursery rhyme

questions.question: Which one of the main characters, depicted by Alexandre Dumas in The Three Musketeers, has a mysterious past connecting him  with Milady de Winter, the female antagonist of the novel?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Athos

questions.question: Author Gabriel García Márquez stresses in this 1985 novel that love-sickness is a literal disease causing pain and other physical symptoms.

options.text: Love in the Time of Cholera

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Love in the Time of Cholera

questions.question: What does the number 451 in the title of Ray Bradburys novel Fahrenheit 451 refer to?

options.text: the temperature at which forests will burn
the temperature required to melt glass
the temperature at which books burn

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the temperature at which books burn

questions.question: Ernest Hemingway belonged to this group of expatriate American writers, who lived in Paris from the end of World War I till the beginning of the Great Depression.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Lost Generation

questions.question: What is the name of the fictional submarine, commanded by Captain Nemo, in the novel Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nautilus

questions.question: Which of the following novels by Agatha Christie features Belgian detective Hercule Poirot?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: What dystopian novel is set in Oceania, an intercontinental super-state ruled by an enigmatic dictator?

options.text: Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nineteen Eighty-Four

questions.question: The novel One Hundred Years of Solitude, written by Nobel Prize-winning author Gabriel García Márquez, was first published in Spanish. What nationality is Márquez?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Colombian

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Gunslinger and Novel
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, gables, parts. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Stephen Kings novel The Gunslinger was written in five parts and published individually in which of the following?

options.text: The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction

questions.question: What was Mark Twains birth name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Samuel L. Clemens

questions.question: When Stephen King began to write The Gunslinger, he typed it on bright green paper.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: How long did it take Stephen King to complete the novel The Dark Tower I: The Gunslinger?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 12 years

questions.question: How does the book The Gunslinger by Stephen King begin?

options.text: The Tower was the first thing Roland thought of when he woke and the last he thought of before sleep.
The man in black fled across the desert, and the gunslinger followed.
The gunslinger sighted, cocked the pistol and prepared to kill the man in black.
Roland looked up, the man in black was silhouetted against the sun.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The man in black fled across the desert, and the gunslinger followed.

questions.question: Originally written in French, this 1949 Samuel Beckett play is about Vladimir and Estragon who expect a man, they barely know, to arrive.

options.text: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Waiting for Godot

questions.question: What are Jakes final words to Roland in the novel The Gunslinger?

options.text: How come I cant have a gun?
I have forgotten the face of my father
Go then, there are other worlds than these.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Go then, there are other worlds than these.

questions.question: In Nathanial Hawthornes The House of the Seven Gables, the destitute Hepzibah Pyncheon lives in the house and supports her brother, Clifford, who has just been released from jail. Why was he in jail?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Murder

questions.question: Who wrote the poem Childe Roland to the Dark Tower Came that inspired Stephen King to write the first novel in The Drak Tower series?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robert Browning

questions.question: Where does Roland first meet Jake in the novel The Gunslinger?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: An abandoned way station

questions.question: In a saloon, the gunslinger from Stephen Kings self-titled novel hears a crowd singing what tune that is well known in our world?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hey Jude

questions.question: This 1857 collection of poems by Charles Baudelaire caused him to be convicted in France of offending the morals of the time, resulting in fines and the banning of 6 of the poems.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Flowers of Evil

questions.question: Published in 1963, The Bell Jar is this poets only novel. It was published under the pseudonym Victoria Lucas.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sylvia Plath

questions.question: In the book The Gunslinger, a gas-pump is found in a tunnel under a mountain and is worshipped as a god. What is the gods name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Amoco

questions.question: In the Novel The Gunslinger, the gunslinger meets a boy called Jake. What is Jakes actual name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Chambers

quizzes.title: Literature Quiz: Mark Twain and Spell
quizzes.description: Test your literature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Literature, charm, born. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This charm helps some Harry Potter characters to breathe underwater or just to block out a bad smell.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bubble-Head Charm

questions.question: In the Harry Potter series of novels, this charm produces bandages and splints.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ferula

questions.question: How many children did Mark Twain and his wife have?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 3 daughters and one son

questions.question: What were Mark Twains favourite animals?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cats

questions.question: This spell from the Harry Potter books causes objects to swell in size.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Engorgio

questions.question: What spell summons an item to the spell caster in the Harry Potter books?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Accio

questions.question: Which spell is used in the Harry Potter novels to unlock a door?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alohomora

questions.question: Where was Mark Twain born and where did he die?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Missouri and Connecticut

questions.question: At the height of his popularity, Mark Twain built one of the oddest and most elaborate homes at that time.  In which eastern city was ythe nineteen-room mansion built?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hartford, Connecticut

questions.question: In the Harry Potter series of books, this spell places enormous pressure upon its target and blasts a hole.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Deprimo

questions.question: What was the name of Mark Twains wife?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Olivia

questions.question: How many of Mark Twains children outlived him?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: one

questions.question: It is generally accepted that the Mark Twain House was designed to resemble which of these?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: a Mississippi riverboat

questions.question: Mark Twain made several costly investment mistakes in his lifetime, and even had to declare bankruptcy.  What was the invention in which he refused to invest?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Telephone

questions.question: What was Mark Twains opinion about slavery?

options.text: Being a southerner, he saw no evil in it.
He believed it was a necessary evil
He kept his true feelings on the subject to himself.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was adamantly against it.
